Asher Hildebrand: an associate professor at Duke University’s Sanford School of Public Policy, states that Congress has voted to deny themselves a pay raise for twelve consecutive years since the last minimum wage increase in 2009.
Josh Lipsky: Director of the Atlantic Council’s GeoEconomics Center, agrees that the claim is inaccurate and misleading, emphasizing that Congress has frozen their salaries every year since the last minimum wage increase.
The Congressional Research Service: CRS) report states that Congress has not actively voted nine times to raise their own salaries in the last 18 years, as claimed. Instead, an automatic adjustment schedule based on changing labor costs was established by the Ethics Reform Act of 1989.
